head.title: Energy Industry Has Friends in Congress

hedline.hl1: Energy Industry Has Friends in Congress

block.p: "Global Warming Heats Up" (editorial, Sept. 18) points out the absurdity of House and Senate committees slashing global change research budgets at the same time that scientists are concluding that human beings are in fact changing the world's climate.

"Global Warming Heats Up" (editorial, Sept. 18) points out the absurdity of House and Senate committees slashing global change research budgets at the same time that scientists are concluding that human beings are in fact changing the world's climate.
It is equivalent to abolishing military surveillance capability just as President Saddam Hussein of Iraq invades Kuwait.

Your analysis misses a key factor, however, behind the nonsensical actions in the House and Senate. The coal, auto and oil industries spend millions on campaign contributions to shape the political landscape in their favor.

For example, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, energy and natural resource corporations invested $23 million in 1992 political campaigns and were rewarded with subsidies and tax breaks worth $8.8 billion.
They invested strategically: seven of the top 10 recipients of energy industry money in the House, and six of the top 10 in the Senate, sat on the committees that oversee national energy policy.

Fossil fuel interests also invest in high-powered lobby groups like the Global Climate Coalition, which works to block climate protection policies at the international negotiations as well as in Washington. The coalition is financed by major petroleum, chemical and auto interests.

For sound public policy to prevail and for democracy to recover, the corrupting influence of money must be systematically eliminated from our political process. RHYS ROTH Project Director Atmosphere Alliance Olympia, Wash., Sept. 18, 1995
